intro: Nostolachma crassifolia, commonly known as the thickleaf mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of various host trees. It has dense, leathery leaves that are typically dark green and glossy, adapted for efficient photosynthesis. The plant produces small, white or pale green flowers, followed by fleshy, berry-like fruits that are important for local wildlife. It is native to parts of Southeast Asia and thrives in tropical and subtropical forest environments. Its parasitic nature allows it to draw water and nutrients from its host, while still maintaining some degree of photosynthetic ability.
